image.altText: A wall collapses during a building fire in the Central Business District of Sydney.

items.synopsis: Fire crews worked throughout the night to mop up a blaze that destroyed a seven-storey heritage building in Sydney's inner city.

title.children: Two 13-year-olds have handed themselves in over 'once in a decade' fire that gutted a Sydney building

image.altText: A close-up of a corporate pwc logo on a reflective glass building panel.

title.children: Parliament House takes on a 'fist fight at the chess club' energy

image.altText: Multiple packets of colourful pharmaceutical medicines.

items.synopsis: The Pharmacy Guild of Australia says 400 drugs are on the "critical" shortage list and 20 per cent of those would be out of stock due to the government's new 60-day script policy. But the data tells a different story.

title.children: We fact checked the Pharmacy Guild's claims about medicine shortages. Here's what we found

image.altText: A close-up shot of a First Nations woman with dyed red hair and glasses

items.synopsis: Victoria's Aboriginal treaty body calls on Facebook to better control racist abuse online, as it counters a surge of hate speech it fears is being fanned by the national debate on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

title.children: 'This shouldn't have to be my day job': Victorian treaty body overwhelmed by 'tidal wave' of racist abuse online

image.altText: Puffing Billy on its route near Melbourne

items.synopsis: Anthony John Hutchins, who admitted to abusing two 12-year-old boys in the 1970s while working as a volunteer at the heritage railway, has been handed a suspended sentence.

title.children: Puffing Billy sex offender who abused young train enthusiasts given suspended jail sentence

image.altText: Gorgeous kelpie in winter coat smiling

items.synopsis: Electricity prices are set to soar come July 1. Here's how you can save some money, while staying warm.

title.children: Energy prices are set to rise up to 25 per cent. Here's how you can save on bills heading into winter

image.altText: A close-up shot of a teenage boy in a black t-shirt lying on the ground with his arms held behind his back by a police officer.

items.synopsis: The 15-year-old boy accused of firing gunshots at a Perth school is remanded to Banksia Hill Detention Centre while his lawyer determines if he should apply for bail.

title.children: Boy charged over school shooting in Perth's north faces court from troubled detention centre

image.altText: A woman standing in the dark staring off into the distance.

items.synopsis: At just two years old, Monica Wallabindi's mother was stolen from her family. She says National Sorry Day isn't about making anyone feel personally guilty or responsible, but acknowledging Australia's past.

title.children: Today is National Sorry Day, but many Indigenous Australians say they're still asked: 'Why should I apologise?'

image.altText: A hand is pouring red wine from a decanter into a wine glass being held by another person

items.synopsis: A Coonawarra winemaker says while the recognition is nice, his product's job is "just to be delicious" rather than win awards.

title.children: Aussie wine with 'classic style' wins best cabernet sauvignon at International Wine Challenge

image.altText: A wide shot of thousands of people dancing in lines in dust.

items.synopsis: The Simpson Desert has been the backdrop of attempts to set world records for Nutbush group dances since 2016. But with the recent passing of American singer Tina Turner, this year's event is set to be bigger than ever.

title.children: Thousands prepare to do the Nutbush in memory of Tina Turner at remote outback festival

image.altText: A woman holding a tree branch, smiling.

items.synopsis: Joy McKean, the first winner of the Golden Guitar who was also the wife and manager of Slim Dusty, has died at the age of 93.

title.children: First Golden Guitar winner Joy McKean dies aged 93

image.altText: NSW Police and salvage personnel lift the body of the wreckage of a seaplane

items.synopsis: NSW Deputy State Coroner Derek Lee said it was "regrettable" carbon monoxide detection was not initially conducted post-mortem.

title.children: Sydney Seaplane crash that killed six people in 2017 likely caused by engine fumes, coroner finds

image.altText: Margo Andrae appearing at Senate committee

items.synopsis: The pork industry slams animal activist groups claiming some posed as plumbers to get into an Australian Pork Limited office.

title.children: Animal activists accused of intimidating pork industry staff, farmers

image.altText: A tourist is silhouetted as he takes pictures of Mount Nuptse in the Everest region.

items.synopsis: Australian engineer Jason Kennison is the 10th climber to die on Mount Everest this spring in one of the deadliest climbing seasons in recent history.

title.children: Why have there been so many deaths on Mount Everest this climbing season?

image.altText: Marcus Stewart stands in a park, dressed in an Akubra and t-shirt bearing the message 'Always Was, Always Will Be'.

items.synopsis: The Uluru dialogue six years ago led to the Statement from the Heart and, ultimately, the upcoming referendum that could deliver constitutional change.

title.children: Voice campaigner calls for overhaul of national Indigenous agency on anniversary of Uluru statement

image.altText: A close-up of an incandescent light-bulb with the word "POWER STRUGGLE" superimposed on it.

items.synopsis: Headline price increases of 25 per cent barely tell the story of struggling households at risk of falling behind in the energy transition.

title.children: Why price hikes are masking an energy divide that threatens to leave poor Australians behind

image.altText: People walking in Brisbane's Queen Street Mall

items.synopsis: ASIC has ordered buy now, pay later provider Humm to stop signing new customers under an interim order, while NSW and Victoria enter a "retail recession" according to analysts. Follow live.

title.children: NSW and Victoria in a 'retail recession' as spending falls flat, Humm told to stop signing new customers, ASX rises

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Latitude has given its investors an update into its cyber attack back in March, saying it expects a half-yearly loss between $95 to $105 million as a result of the incident. That includes a $53 million provision which accounts for costs associated with the cyber incident, including remediation costs. That figure however doesn't account for regulatory fines, potential class actions, future system changes or assumed insurance proceeds. Latitude is now expecting a profit between $ 15 million and $25 million. The company also says it has contacted all affected customers (past and present) impacted by the data breach, and there has been no suspicious activity in its systems since March 16. The incident is also under investigation by the AFP, and Latitude says they're cooperating fully with the OAIC. Latitude also says their regular business operations are now back online after around "five weeks" of delays. (Sidenote, but if you're a Latitude customer and want to get in touch, I've done stories in the past couple of months on the breach. Feel free to send me an email at ainsworth.kate@abc.net.au or you can use the comment button above — I won't share them on the blog.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Latitude expecting a substantial hit to their profit after cyber attack

children.content: Latitude has given its investors an update into its cyber attack back in March, saying it expects a half-yearly loss between
$95 to $105 million
as a result of the incident.
That includes a
$53 million provision

which accounts for costs associated with the cyber incident, including remediation costs. That figure however doesn't account for regulatory fines, potential class actions, future system changes or assumed insurance proceeds.
Latitude is now expecting a profit between $
15 million and $25 million
The company also says it has contacted all affected customers (past and present) impacted by the data breach, and there has been no suspicious activity in its systems since March 16.
The incident is also under investigation by the AFP, and Latitude says they're cooperating fully with the OAIC.
Latitude also says their regular business operations are now back online after around "five weeks" of delays.
(Sidenote, but if you're a Latitude customer and want to get in touch, I've done stories in the past couple of months on the breach. Feel free to send me an email at
ainsworth.kate@abc.net.au
or you can use the comment button above — I won't share them on the blog.)

props.alt: A phone screen that has the Latitude Financial website open.

children.content: The data of Latitude customers remains at risk of being released after the cyber attack.
(ABC News: Dannielle Maguire)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The names of around 50 senior members of consulting firm PwC, the subject of intense political and media scrutiny, are edging closer to being known. The names are noted in heavily-redacted emails about a plot to use secret government information to win clients by helping them avoid not-yet-created taxes. Those emails were released by a Senate committee earlier this month. Just now, Greens Senator Barbara Pocock attempted to read the names at a Senate Estimates hearing. After a short recess she has held off, pending legal advice. "Thank you to all here for their thoughtful consideration of this matter," she said at its resumption. "I believe there's a strong public interest in those names of those involved in recent events in PwC being in the public realm, but I accept the decision and respect the decision that we've just made as a committee that we will seek the advice of the clerk and proceed accordingly. " I believe that the truth and the names of people involved in this event will [come] out and I think that's it's important the Australian public have that knowledge sooner rather than later. Thank you." Treasury has referred the former head of international tax at PwC Peter-John Collins to the Australian Federal Police for consideration of a criminal decision. Australia has strict defamation laws, but things said in parliament and most courts are "protected speech" meaning they can be discussed and reported more freely.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC names close to being revealed

children.content: The names of around 50 senior members of consulting firm PwC, the subject of intense political and media scrutiny, are edging closer to being known.

The names are noted in heavily-redacted emails about a plot to use secret government information to win clients by helping them avoid not-yet-created taxes. Those emails were released by a Senate committee earlier this month.
Just now,
Greens Senator Barbara Pocock attempted to read the names
at a Senate Estimates hearing. After a short recess
she has held off, pending legal advice
"Thank you to all here for their thoughtful consideration of this matter," she said at its resumption.
"I believe there's a
strong public interest in those names of those involved in recent events in PwC
being in the public realm, but I accept the decision and respect the decision that we've just made as a committee that we will seek the advice of the clerk and proceed accordingly.
I believe that the truth and the names of people involved in this event will [come] out
and I think that's it's important the Australian public have that knowledge sooner rather than later. Thank you."
Treasury has referred the former head of international tax at PwC Peter-John Collins to the Australian Federal Police for consideration of a criminal decision.
Australia has strict defamation laws, but things said in parliament and most courts are "protected speech" meaning they can be discussed and reported more freely.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Callam Pickering, Asia-Pacific economist at Indeed says the retail figures signal that NSW and Victoria are experiencing a "retail recession". He says the retail figures show momentum has ground to a halt as cost of living pressures keep building in the economy. "Given strong population growth and rising prices, it's clear that Australian households, on average, are consuming fewer retail products than they did last year," he said. "High cost-of-living, rising mortgage rates and the sharp decline in inflation-adjusted wages will make things difficult for the retail sector over the remainder of the year. That will be partially offset by high immigration and low unemployment. "We anticipate a considerable slowdown in household spending over the second half of the year." He says looking at state and territory figures, two of Australians biggest states are in a recession when it comes to retail. "Both New South Wales and Victoria are in a retail recession that began in the December quarter last year," he said. "By comparison, spending in South Australia is booming and reached a record level in April, following events such as the AFL Gather Round."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW, Victoria are experiencing a 'retail recession'

children.content: Callam Pickering, Asia-Pacific economist at Indeed says the retail figures signal that NSW and Victoria are experiencing a "retail recession".
He says the retail figures show momentum has ground to a halt as cost of living pressures keep building in the economy.
"Given strong population growth and rising prices, it's clear that Australian households, on average, are consuming fewer retail products than they did last year," he said.

"High cost-of-living, rising mortgage rates and the sharp decline in inflation-adjusted wages will make things difficult for the retail sector over the remainder of the year. That will be partially offset by high immigration and low unemployment.
"We anticipate a considerable slowdown in household spending over the second half of the year."
He says looking at state and territory figures, two of Australians biggest states are in a recession when it comes to retail.
"Both New South Wales and Victoria are in a retail recession that began in the December quarter last year," he said.
"By comparison, spending in South Australia is booming and reached a record level in April, following events such as the AFL Gather Round."

image.altText: Two Australian army infantry fighting vehicles.

items.synopsis: Lucrative construction work on new high-tech Army infantry fighting vehicles (IFVs) could be sent overseas under an option being considered by the Albanese government to acquire the lethal land capability more urgently.

image.altText: Black and white photo of Gerd Heidemann standing, holding two large books, before group of men seated near microphones.

image.altText: A still from a video of a Vietnamese man ith red shirt sprinkling herbs onto a soup.

image.altText: A Russian military officer walks past the 9M729 land-based cruise missile on display with its launcher

image.altText: A wanted poster shows a group of men wanted, some have an ex through their pic.
